Welcome the class. Ask students if they like stories about history or news. Introduce the 'Border Story' as a real event in their region.
B1/B2 LISTENING

A BORDER STORY

Inside the Thai-Cambodian Conflict

Elicit what students already know about Preah Vihear. If they are unsure, explain it is a beautiful ancient temple that both countries claim. Use the picture of the soldiers to set a serious but curious tone.
TASK 1

What's going on?

  • Look at the temple. What do you know about the Thai-Cambodian border?
  • Have you ever heard of the Preah Vihear Temple? Why is there a fight here?
  • What does it mean to 'flee'? Why would families do this?
Transition slide. Tell students: 'Before we watch the news, we need some Power Words to help us understand the story.'

PART 1

Power Words

Explain the strategy. TEACHER TIP: Matching words is like a puzzle. Once you finish, you can use them to talk about the real world! Emphasize that 'Thinking in Thai' is a useful tool.

Strategy: Learning 'Power Words'

üß≠ When words are difficult, don't worry! Here is the plan:

  • üé≠ Check the vibe: Does the word seem happy or scary?
  • üáπüá≠ Think in Thai: Find a word in Thai that feels the same.
  • üó£Ô∏è Speak it: Let's practice saying them together!
Drill pronunciation. CCQ: 'If a doctor gives you medicine for a headache, is he mitigating the pain?' (Yes).

To make something less serious or painful.

"Let's try to mitigate the problem by talking peacefully."

Drill pronunciation. This is a key word for the conflict. Ask: 'Is retaliating usually a good way to stay peaceful?' (No).

Drill pronunciation. Explain that 'cease' means 'stop'.

Drill pronunciation. Ask students if they have ever seen an evacuation (fire drill or flood).

Transition: 'Now we are going to watch the actual BBC Field Report. Be ready to use your ears and your eyes!'

PART 2

The Field Report

Help students feel confident. PRO TIP: If you see smoke or running people, you already know the story is about conflict! Remind them that understanding the 'vibe' is a real world listening skill.

Strategy: The Big Picture

üì∫ When we watch the news, we don't need to understand everything.

  • üòü Watch faces: Are they happy or scared?
  • üéôÔ∏è Listen for tone: Is the reporter excited or calm?
  • üì∞ What is the topic? What is the main story?

The Situation Today

Observe & Discuss:

  • Is it getting better or worse?
  • What do you see happening?
  • How do the families feel?
Play the video. Monitor student reactions. If the video is too fast, you can play it twice.
Confirm the gist. Ask for one or two reasons why they think it's getting worse (e.g. 'soldiers', 'crying people').
REPLAY CLIP

What did we see?

CORRECT ANSWER
It is getting WORSE (Escalating).
THE EVIDENCE
"This confrontation is one of the most severe since the ceasefire back in July."
EXPLANATION
The reporter highlights that violence is increasing and more families are fleeing than before.
Direct students to their specific tasks. B1 focuses on families/schools; B2 focuses on accusations and claims.

Strategy: Mission Directive: Task 3

‚öîÔ∏è Now look at Task 3. We are splitting the mission roles:

  • üë§ B1 Agents: You'll be listening for the Human Impact (how it affects people).
  • üèõÔ∏è B2 Agents: You'll be listening for the Diplomatic Friction (the blame game).
Give students a moment to prepare their notebooks. Advise them to only listen for their assigned facts.

Strategy: Listening for Detail

üìù How to capture intelligence effectively:

  • üîë Identify Keywords: Listen for specific nouns (shelters, air force, targets).
  • üë§ Identify Sources: Note who is making the claim (Thai side vs. Cambodian side).
  • ‚úçÔ∏è Quick Notes: Use symbols or 1-word hints. Don't write full sentences yet!
Set the timer. Walk around and help students identify the specific claims from the reporter.
TASK 3

Fact-Finding

B1: Families

Find 3 ways the conflict hurts ordinary families.

B2: The Blame Game

Who said: 'Targeting military sites'? Who Denied starting the fight?

Discuss how these feel to a student (especially the 'No school' part - would they like that or would it be scary?).
REPLAY CLIP

B1 Facts: Families

CORRECT ANSWER
Shelters, Schools Closed, Health Issues
THE EVIDENCE
"A lot of people have moved to shelters... Schools have been shut, meaning students cannot go to school on either side."
EXPLANATION
The clip confirms the humanitarian impact on civilians and the disruption of local education.
Highlight the 'Blame Game'. Ask: 'In a fight, does anyone ever say they started it?' (Rarely).
REPLAY CLIP

B2 Facts: The Blame Game

CORRECT ANSWER
Thai: 'Targeting military' | Cambodia: 'Denied Responsibility'
THE EVIDENCE
"Thailand's air force said it struck Cambodian military targets... Cambodia has denied provoking violence."
EXPLANATION
Both governments use specific language to justify their actions or deny fault.
Transition: 'Now, you are the leaders. Can you solve this problem?'

PART 3

Reaching Peace

Model some soft language. THE WIN: A good solution makes the fighting stop! Encourage them to use the Power Words like 'mitigate' and 'ceasefire' during the task.

Strategy: Reaching a Deal

ü§ù A good leader is kind but firm.

  • üïäÔ∏è Soft phrases: 'We think we should...'
  • üè´ Be a helper: 'How can we help the schools?'
  • üåà Future thinking: 'Let's stop the fear.'
Monitor closely. This is the heart of the lesson. Encourage students to talk to each other and compromise.
TASK 4

Peace Deal

Group A: Helping People

Create a 3-step plan (Food, Doctors, Schools).

Group B: The Rules

Create 3 rules for peace (Meetings, No blame, Observors).

Final wrap up. Praise their diplomatic skills. Tell them they have learned how to look at complex news stories as global citizens.
WELL DONE!

Peace at last!
